Hi friends I am Niharika and welcome back
to a new lesson. In today's lesson we are

gonna look at binomial pairs joined with the
conjunction and. This is a new thing right?

Binomial Pairs - So what exactly is a binomial
pair? Binomial pair is an expression using

two words which are joined by a conjunction.
SO in English we have many binomials pairs

that we use in our daily conversations and
they are usually joined with the conjunction

'and' or they are joined by the conjunction
'or' okay, and even there are binomial pairs

with the similar sound. When two words sound
similar and they are joined by one of the

conjunctions, well those expressions are also
called as binomial pairs. SO, we are gonna

look at six binomial pairs here in this lesson
and they really simple and they are specifically

joined using the conjunction 'and'.
So let's get started.
The very first one that

we have for you is sick and tired. Well I
am sure you have heard this before, right!

Yes, sick and tired is one of the binomial
pairs and the meaning of this phrase is that

when you are very annoyed and frustrated with
something. So .... Okay, that happen right?

At times we are so annoyed and frustrated
about something and we just want to talk about

it, rather than using these big words you
can use one this expression which is sick

and tired. I am sick and tired of my neighbour
playing loud music every evening. It means

that I am so done with it, I am so annoyed,
I am so frustrated with the loud music. So

this is the expression that you can use. And
yes it is joined by the conjunction 'and'.

Now, always remember all these binomial pairs,
the two words that we use to join together,

these words are fixed, they cannot be used
in a interchangeable manner, like you cannot

say that I am tired and sick. It's always
gonna be I am sick and tired . Okay, so they
are always fixed.

The second expression that I have for you
is neat and tidy. Wow, look at your closet,

it is so neat and tidy. So neat and tidy,
it means that it;s not messy, it's very clean

and it's very organised. SO rather than saying
oh look at your closet its so nice, its so

clean, its so organised Well use one of the
binomial pair - say its neat and tidy.

The third expression that I have for you is
short and sweet - Ohh wow, your speech was

so short and sweet! So short and sweet is
something which is to the point, someone says

something to the point. Like in award functions,
there are actors, there are singers and directors

who love to talk, they go on and on but then
there are some actors who just keep it very

short, their speech is to the point, they
want to thank someone, they just want to thank

to be appreciated and awarded, they just keep
it very short. So that's short and sweet speech.

Another expression that I have for you here
is odds and ends. Now odds and ends are these

various things, the various items which are
very small and which are of less value and

not very important. So some things which are
tiny items, which are not of big value and

which are not important. The small, unimportant
items. Like for example - This closet of mine

has all odds and ends. So this means the closet
is full of small things which are not very

important to me and which are not of great
value either. Okay, so that's how you can
use this expression.

The next one is loud and clear. Am I loud
and clear to you ? Loud and clear it means

Are you able to understand me or to be understood
easily. The boss was very loud and clear about

his agenda. It means that he spoke to the
point and which was understood by the team

members in a very nice way. So he was loud
and clear about his agenda or whatever he

wants to do , he's very clear about it, he
was to the point.

And then the last one that I have for you
is by and large. Have you heard that before.

Yes, it's very commonly used for the things
we talk about in general or on 
the whole. So , for example the restaurant

is great, couple of dishes were not so good
but by and large it is a nice place to go

on a Saturday. So in general the restaurant
is a nice place to go eat on a Saturday night.

SO when you are talking about something in
general or on the whole, you end up using

this expression. Another example - the amusement
park is not very spacious, but by and large

it is a good place for kids. So in general
the place is good for kids.

So start using these expressions, remember
these expressions in English are called binomial

pairs, which means two words joined by a conjunction.
And in this lesson we specifically looked

at words which are joined by the conjunction
' and' . So start using them, keep practising
and I will back with a new lesson, till then you take care.
